questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous involvement of the gut

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but they have distinct pathological and clinical features.

 

Key Features of Crohn's Disease:

 

  • Segmental involvement: Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, segmental involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, known as "skip lesions." This contrasts with ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous, uninterrupted inflammation of the colon.

 

Continuous Involvement of the Gut:

 

This feature is typical of ulcerative colitis, where the inflammation is continuous and starts from the rectum extending proximally in a continuous manner without skipping any areas. In Crohn's disease, the inflammation is discontinuous, with normal areas interspersed between inflamed regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of colon cancer: This is true for Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, as the risk of progression to malignancy is generally lower, especially for non-colonic Crohn's.

 

Option C. Higher risk of perianal fistula: Crohn's disease has a higher risk of perianal complications, including fistulas, due to the transmural nature of its inflammation.

 

Option D. Rarely present with daily hematochezia: Daily hematochezia is less common in Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, which is more likely to cause continuous bloody diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

 

Key Differences Between Crohn’s Disease & Ulcerative Colitis:

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the paternal chromosome. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a segment on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13.

 

This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, hyperphagia leading to obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and distinct physical features.

 

Prader-Willi syndrome can also occur due to maternal uniparental disomy (Maternal UPD), where two copies of the maternal chromosome are present, and no paternal copy is active.

 

These two mechanisms—paternal deletion and maternal uniparental disomy—are the main causes of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

In rare cases, an issue with imprinting itself can also lead to the syndrome, but the primary focus is on the two causes mentioned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angelman syndrome: Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It presents with severe intellectual disability, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter, which differs from Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option C. VHL syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with mutations on chromosome 3, leading to various tumors, including hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is unrelated to chromosome 15 deletions.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra chromosome 18, presenting with severe intellectual disability, heart defects, and characteristic physical anomalies. It does not involve deletions on chromosome 15.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

questions.text: In which urinary components is Tamm Horsfall protein present? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) urine cast

 

Tamm Horsfall protein is present in urine cast.

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein, also known as uromodulin, is a glycoprotein produced by the cells lining the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidneys. It is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine Crystal: Urine crystals are solid particles found in urine, often composed of substances like calcium oxalate, uric acid, or struvite. They are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option C. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in vertebrates. It is not associated with Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Option D. Bile Salts: Bile salts are components of bile, which aid in the digestion of fats. They are not found in urine and are not related to Tamm-Horsfall protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamm-Horsfall protein (uromodulin) is present in urine casts and is the most abundant protein found in normal human urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FISH

 

Explanation

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration: While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.

 

Option C. LAP score: Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Explanation:

 

In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.

 

Among the three early markers of myocardial injury, three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.

 

Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery?

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery
  5. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. v

 

Explanation

 

All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.

 

Other options

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery: Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery: Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening muscle weakness and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The patient presents with features of scleroderma and dermatomyositis overlap syndrome. Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with this overlap syndrome, tends to produce nucleolar pattern in your ANA immunofluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Associated with the diffuse form of scleroderma and are also known as anti-fibrillarin antibodies.
 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).
 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which predominantly causes interstitial lung disease (ILD), mechanic's hands, myositis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. It is not associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with overlap syndromes involving scleroderma and myositis.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray, what is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The X-ray provided shows air under the right diaphragm, which is a clear sign of a hollow viscus perforation, specifically pneumoperitoneum. This occurs when air escapes from the gastrointestinal tract into the peritoneal cavity, typically due to a perforation. The key visual cue here is the presence of air under the right diaphragm, as air under the left diaphragm can sometimes be due to the presence of the stomach and may cause confusion. In the clinical setting, such a finding would correlate with symptoms like acute abdomen, severe pain, guarding, and rigidity.

 

For the diagnosis of conditions like a suspected perforation, the initial and primary investigation recommended is a chest X-ray PA (posteroanterior) in an erect position. While a Contrast-Enhanced CT (CCT) with oral contrast is more sensitive and can precisely locate the site of the leak, it's generally not necessary if the chest X-ray has already confirmed the diagnosis.

 

Upon confirming a perforation, immediate actions include administering IV fluids for resuscitation followed by urgent surgical intervention, typically an exploratory laparotomy, due to the emergent nature of gastrointestinal perforations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal perforation: While an esophageal perforation could also lead to air escaping into the mediastinum or other areas, it typically presents with pneumomediastinum rather than air under the diaphragm.

 

Option B. SBO (Small Bowel Obstruction): SBO typically presents with dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels on an X-ray, rather than free air under the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus involves twisting of a loop of intestine, which can lead to obstruction and possibly ischemia, but does not usually present with free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of air under the right diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a strong indicator of a hollow viscus perforation and is considered a surgical emergency

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U*V/P, where U is?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine urea in mg /100ml

 

'U' in the urea clearance stands for urine concentration of urea in mg /100ml.

 

The formula for renal clearance of a substance is,

 

Clearance (C = U × V / P),

 

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance in mg / ml
  • V = Urine flow rate in ml/min
  • P = Plasma concentration of substance in mg /ml.

 

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OAE

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening. OAE testing is a simple, quick, and non-invasive method that measures sounds (emissions) produced by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to an auditory stimulus. This test is highly effective for detecting hearing loss in newborns and can be performed shortly after birth. If the OAE test results are normal, no further testing is needed. However, if the OAE test is abnormal, further evaluation with Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is recommended after three months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BERA: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used if OAE results are abnormal. It is more comprehensive but not used as the initial screening test due to its complexity and requirement for specialized equipment.

 

Option C. PTA: Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) is not suitable for newborns as it requires behavioral responses to sound, which cannot be reliably obtained from newborns.

 

Option D. Impedance: Impedance audiometry measures the function of the middle ear but is not used for initial newborn hearing screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

choices.text: Denotes latent CMV infection
Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
Indicates acute CMV infection
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

 

IgG avidity assays measure the binding strength between IgG antibodies and virus that can help distinguish a primary CMV infection from a past infection. Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Denotes latent CMV infection: While the presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicates a past infection and potential latent infection, it does not specifically denote the current state of latency.

 

Option B. Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes: Anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and potential latent infection but do not confer immunity to all serotypes of CMV.

 

Option C. Indicates acute CMV infection: The presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies alone does not indicate an acute infection; it suggests past exposure. Acute CMV infection is usually indicated by the presence of anti-CMV IgM antibodies or a significant rise in IgG levels over time.

 

Educational objective

 

An IgG avidity assay is a useful tool to differentiate between a primary CMV infection and a past infection. Low avidity IgG indicates a recent infection, whereas high avidity IgG indicates a past infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: An unconscious patient in ICU is on endotracheal intubation and now needs a tracheostomy. What type of tube should be considered in this situation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cuffed tracheostomy tube

 

Explanation:

 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube: This type of tube is preferred for patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation. The cuff can be inflated to:

 

  • Prevent Aspiration: The cuff acts as a barrier, preventing secretions from the upper airway from entering the trachea and lungs.
  • Maintain Positive Pressure Ventilation: The cuff ensures that air does not leak around the tracheostomy tube, which is crucial for effective mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncuffed tracheostomy tube: Not suitable for patients who are at risk of aspiration or who require positive pressure ventilation since it does not provide a seal.

 

Option C. Metallic tracheostomy tube: Typically used in long-term tracheostomies but lacks a cuff, which means it cannot prevent aspiration or maintain a seal for positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Endotracheal tube: This is used for short-term airway management and is not suitable for long-term tracheostomy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For unconscious patients in ICU requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation, a cuffed tracheostomy tube is the preferred choice. The cuff provides a seal to prevent aspiration and ensure effective positive pressure ventilation, making it safer and more effective for such patients.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 11

 

The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimulus.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. Though he also flexes on one side (M4), the higher response is counted in GCS.

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated based on eye response, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score indicating the level of consciousness.

choices.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.

 

 

After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.

 

Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.

 

Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: A lady with mitral stenosis who is bedridden, develops sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, she has a swollen red limb with pain in the calf. What is the clinical diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, who is bedridden with mitral stenosis, presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb with calf pain. These clinical features strongly suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sudden shortness of breath indicates that a thrombus from the DVT has likely embolized to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism. This is a common and potentially life-threatening complication in bedridden patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: This is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, typically secondary to heart failure, and does not present with a swollen, red limb or calf pain.

 

Option C. Cerebral embolism: This would present with neurological deficits, not shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus passes from the venous to the arterial system through a cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). While this could be considered if there were signs of arterial embolism, the presentation here is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in bedridden patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and clinical signs of deep vein thrombosis, such as a swollen, red, painful limb.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.

 

Miliary tuberculosis:

 

  • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • Hematogenous spread.

 

Miliary pattern D/D:   

 

  • Healed varicella
  • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Silicosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular tumor found in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for JNA is Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT is preferred because it effectively delineates the bony margins and the extent of the tumor, including any bone erosion. The contrast enhancement helps in identifying the vascular nature of the tumor, which is crucial in differentiating JNA from other masses in the nasal cavity, such as adenoids or carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is helpful for assessing orbital and cranial extensions of the tumor but is not the primary choice for initial diagnosis. It does not provide as clear an image of the bony structures as CECT does.

 

Option C. DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy): While DNE can visualize a mass in the nasal cavity, it cannot determine the type of mass or its vascular nature. It is less informative than imaging studies in the diagnosis of JNA.

 

Option D. Biopsy: Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected JNA due to the high risk of severe bleeding given the vascular nature of the tumor. Attempting a biopsy can lead to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:


The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following feature is correct on the basis of given karyotype? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

 

Given karyotyping image shows '47, XXY' abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flat occiput: This feature is typically seen in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

 

Option C. Webbing of neck and lymphedema: These are characteristic features of Turner syndrome (45, X).

 

Option D. Short stature and polydactyly: These are features seen in Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by gynecomastia, long limbs, small testes, and infertility.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 316-317

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

 

The patient's presentation of worsening ear pain, drainage, and redness behind the ear, along with a prominent right pinna pointing down and out, is indicative of a complication of acute otitis media, specifically acute mastoiditis. Acute mastoiditis is characterized by inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells, often resulting in a post-auricular abscess, as seen in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Otitis externa, or external ear canal infection, typically presents with pain, discharge, and sometimes swelling of the ear canal, but does not usually cause post-auricular redness or a displaced pinna.

 

Option B. Otitis media with effusion: Otitis media with effusion involves the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It does not present with post-auricular redness or abscess.

 

Option D. Coalescent Mastoiditis: Coalescent mastoiditis is a more advanced stage of mastoiditis where the bony septa between mastoid air cells break down, forming a common cavity. This diagnosis could be considered if the condition had been present for a longer duration. However, the acute presentation described fits acute mastoiditis more accurately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  1. Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  2. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  3. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome: Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  4. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subepithelial deposits

 

A child with skin infection followed by passage of cola colored urine is suggestive of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The worsening of creatinine from 2.5mg/dl to 4.5 mg/dl is suggestive of worsen of his condition in a short span of time. This prompts a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

 

  • Pathology: RPGN is characterized by the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, which are formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.
  • Clinical Features: Rapid deterioration of renal function, often following an infection such as streptococcal throat or skin infection.
  • Crescents can be seen on light microscopy in RPGN (especially crescentic PSGN).
  • But electron microscopy (EM) will still show subepithelial deposits, which is diagnostic of PSGN.
  • So, even though the clinical course is RPGN, the question asked what you see on EM - hence the correct answer is Subepithelial deposits
  • Type I: Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Type II: Immune complex-mediated (e.g., PSGN, lupus nephritis)
  • Type III: Pauci-immune (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendothelial deposits: Seen in conditions like lupus nephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typical for RPGN following PSGN.

 

Option C. Crescents in glomeruli: Suggest RPGN, but the specific hallmark of PSGN is subepithelial humps (crescents may appear if it evolves into RPGN, but not diagnostic)

 

Option D. Mesangial deposits: Commonly seen in IgA nephropathy and other mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, not specific for RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, crescents can be seen on light microscopy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSTEMI:  NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction) can present with similar symptoms but requires positive cardiac troponins for diagnosis. The absence of troponin data makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Unstable Angina: Unstable angina presents with similar symptoms but without elevation of cardiac biomarkers. As mentioned, differentiating between NSTEMI and unstable angina is not possible without troponin levels, which are not provided.

 

Option D. Acute Myocarditis: Acute myocarditis would typically present with a history of viral infection and can show non-specific ECG changes, often including sinus tachycardia. The patient's history and ECG findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tall R waves, ST depression, and upright T waves in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of a posterior myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

This is Bitot’s spot shown in the picture due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B:

 

  • Function: Vitamin B is a group of vitamins that includes B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins play various roles in energy production, brain function, and cell metabolism
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Deficiencies in different B vitamins can result in a range of symptoms, including fatigue, neurological issues, anemia, and skin problems.

 

Option C. Vitamin C:

 

  • Function: Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, wound healing, and the absorption of iron from plant-based foods. It also acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: A lack of vitamin C can lead to scurvy, which includes symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and skin issues.

 

Option D. Vitamin K:

 

  • Function: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting and bone health. It helps in the synthesis of proteins involved in clot formation and bone mineralization.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin K deficiency can result in bleeding disorders and weakened bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 530

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filiform

 

The filiform papillae are the most numerous of the lingual papillae on the tongue, but they do not contain taste buds. They are primarily responsible for the general sensations of touch, temperature, pressure, and texture. Unlike other types of papillae—such as foliate, fungiform, and circumvallate—filiform papillae are not involved in the sensation of taste, which is a special sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foliate: These papillae are located on the lateral sides of the tongue and contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in sensing sweet and sour tastes.

 

Option C. Fungiform Papilla: These are found on the top of the tongue and are involved in sensing sweet, sour, and salty tastes. They contain taste buds.

 

Option D. Circumvallate: These are located at the back of the tongue and are primarily involved in sensing bitter tastes. They also contain taste buds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

choices.text: Conservative management with observation and ice chips.
Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site

questions.text: A 10 year old girl post tonsillectomy ate a packet of chips 2-3 days after the surgery and now came to the hospital with oral bleed. What shall be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antibiotics with semisolid food

 

Antibiotics with semisolid food is one approach to manage postoperative bleeding after tonsillectomy. The rationale behind antibiotics is to prevent or treat any possible infection that might have been caused by the chips. Semisolid food is recommended to minimize the mechanical irritation to the tonsillar fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical exploration may be required if the bleeding is significant or if it does not stop with conservative measures. This would involve returning to the operating room to identify the source of bleeding and achieve hemostasis.

 

Option C. Conservative management with observation and ice chips can be appropriate for minor bleeding. Ice chips can help with vasoconstriction and pain relief. Observation is crucial to ensure that bleeding does not worsen.

 

Option D. Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site may be necessary if the bleeding is active and significant. This would typically be done under controlled conditions, possibly in the operating room.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a potential complication that can be managed conservatively with antibiotics and dietary modifications, such as semisolid food, to prevent further mechanical trauma to the surgical site. However, the approach to management should be tailored to the severity of the bleeding and the clinical condition of the patient, with more aggressive interventions like surgical exploration or cauterization reserved for significant or persistent bleeding.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA that caused crush injury. Within 3 days of the injury and post-amputation, crepitus was present and the wound was reddish brown. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gas gangrene 

 

Gas gangrene, caused by Clostridium bacteria, presents with rapid onset of severe pain, edema, and crepitus due to gas production in the tissues. The wound may appear reddish-brown or bronze-colored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressing infection of the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, causing severe pain, skin discoloration, and systemic toxicity. However, it typically does not present with gas production.

 

Option C. Tetanus: Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani and typically presents with muscle stiffness and spasms due to the neurotoxins produced by the bacteria. It does not involve crepitus or tissue gas.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, warmth, and pain in the affected area. It does not typically involve gas production or crepitus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gas gangrene, characterized by rapid tissue destruction, gas production, and a reddish-brown appearance of the wound, should be promptly recognized and managed due to its potential for rapid progression and systemic complications.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: A child is presenting with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash and spots in the oral cavity as shown in the given image, what is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

The clinical presentation of fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, rash, and characteristic spots in the oral cavity is indicative of measles. The spots shown in the image are Koplik spots, which are pathognomonic for measles.

 

Key Points about Measles:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by an RNA paramyxovirus.
  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Koplik Spots: Small, white lesions with a red base typically found opposite the lower second molar.
    • Rash: Starts behind the ears (retroauricular) and spreads downwards.
    • Other Symptoms: Fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and cough.

 

Common Complications:

 

  • Most Common: Serous otitis media.
  • Serious Complication: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a late and fatal complication.
  • Histopathology: Presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells in lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox: Incorrect. Chicken pox (varicella) presents with a vesicular rash that typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs and face. Oral lesions are not specific to chicken pox.

 

Option C. Mumps: Incorrect. Mumps typically presents with parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) and may have associated fever and orchitis in males. Koplik spots are not a feature of mumps.

 

Option D. Rubella: Incorrect. Rubella presents with a fine, pink rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs, but it does not present with Koplik spots. It is usually milder than measles and may have postauricular lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Koplik spots, along with fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis, and rash, is highly indicative of measles.

choices.text: Increased formation of Heinz body
Males and females can be affected
Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells' ability to handle oxidative stress.

 

This is incorrect. G6PD deficiency actually increases oxidative stress inside red blood cells because the reduced NADPH levels lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione. This makes the cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased formation of Heinz body: Correct because this is a hallmark of G6PD deficiency due to oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Males and females can be affected: Correct; while males are more commonly affected, females can also be affected due to the X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option C. Reduced NADPH: Correct because this is a direct consequence of G6PD deficiency as the enzyme is essential for NADPH production in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: Post-partum IUCD insertion can be inserted till? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48h

 

Postpartum IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is classified into early postpartum and late postpartum insertion.

 

  • Early Postpartum IUCD (PPIUCD): This can be further divided into:
     
    • Within 10 minutes of placental delivery: This is known as immediate PPIUCD insertion.
    • After 10 minutes but within 48 hours of delivery: This is still considered early postpartum insertion and can be performed either after vaginal delivery or during a cesarean section.
       

If the IUCD is not inserted within this 48-hour window, it cannot be inserted until after six weeks postpartum. This period between 48 hours and six weeks is a contraindicated window for IUCD insertion due to the increased risk of expulsion and complications.

 

  • Late Postpartum IUCD: This insertion is done after six weeks postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postpartum IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery or after six weeks postpartum. The period between 48 hours and six weeks is contraindicated for IUCD insertion.
